Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Expressing attitudes of belief and other mental states in Navajo

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Although understudied languages native to the Americas have long shaped linguistic theories of sounds, word formation, and sentence structure, formal semantic theory - the theory of meaning - has only recently started to be driven by these languages. Understudied languages demonstrate what words, and which strategies for constructing meaningful sentences out of individual words, are universal and innate to all human languages, and which are not. This research project examines the expression of mental states such as beliefs and desires in Navajo, an understudied language spoken in the southwest of the United States. Examining the semantics of an understudied language is valuable in two ways. First, the products of semantic research readily lend themselves to use in documentary and pedagogical materials which will aid in language revitalization. It is crucial that linguistic research coordinate with language revitalization efforts since many languages of the Americas, including Navajo, are underdocumented and no longer acquired as a first language by a significant number of children. Second, such work enriches linguists' understanding of the ways in which certain languages can vary in their construction and expression of complex meaning. All previous formal semantic research on beliefs and desires focused on languages related to English, where special verbs like think or want are used to express either belief or desire, respectively: if research only considers English and its relatives, however, linguists might - perhaps incorrectly - conclude that this is the only way that human languages can grammatically express the mental states corresponding to beliefs and desires.

Navajo is an ideal language of study since its method of expressing beliefs and desires appears to be very different from what is found in English. Navajo lacks specialized attitude verbs corresponding to English verbs like think and want: the same verb appears both in sentences expressing beliefs and in sentences expressing desires. The project's first theoretical goal is to determine what other grammatical resources are used in such sentences to disambiguate between beliefs and desires. Pilot work shows that speakers use different temporal (tense, aspect) and modal morphology depending on the kind of attitude they intend to express. The project's second theoretical goal is to study the truth and felicity conditions of Navajo attitude sentences - under what conditions is a sentence true and 'natural-sounding'? - and contrast them with their English translations. Existing documentation of Navajo expressions of belief and desire provide English translations of Navajo sentences but give no further clues to their truth and felicity conditions: translations are only partial clues to meaning and may obscure deeper between attitudes in English and Navajo. Interviews will be conducted with Navajo speakers at the Navajo Language Academy (NLA), an annual workshop attended by Navajo speakers and language teachers and held in, or near, the Navajo Nation. The co-PI will incorporate findings into an NLA course in linguistic theory and research methodology designed to enable Navajo speakers to conduct research on their own language. In addition, research findings will be summarized in an accessible, theory-neutral way and will be made available to Navajo speakers engaged in projects of language revitalization and education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

Title: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Expressing attitudes of belief and other mental states in Navajo

PI: Rajesh Bhatt [co-PI: PhD student Elizabeth Bogal-Allbritten]

Award Number: 1451265

This project investigated the expression of attitudes of belief and desire in Navajo, an understudied and threatened language spoken in the southwestern United States. While there has been a significant increase in semantic investigation of understudied languages of the Americas, mental attitudes in these languages have received no detailed formal attention. This project begins to fill this gap by providing a detailed picture of Navajo attitudes and developing fieldwork materials that can be used by other researchers to examine attitudes in a wider range of understudied languages. 

 

The Navajo method of expressing beliefs and desires is of particular intellectual interest because it is typologically very unfamiliar: the verb nízin appears in sentences translated into English using attitude verbs think, want, and wish. The co-PI studied the meaning (i.e. truth and felicity conditions) of sentences with nízin by using contexts that were carefully designed to target either a belief or desire interpretation. The co-PI demonstrated that material (particles or aspectual morphology) in the embedded clause established a generally unambiguous meaning for the sentence as a whole. In addition, the co-PI identified one type of nízin sentence which was systematically ambiguous between expressing belief vs. desire; the co-PI demonstrated that these sentences were truly ambiguous, rather than vague, and argued that their ambiguity correlated with an ambiguity found in main clauses of similar morphosyntactic shape.

 

The results from Navajo strongly support a recent theoretical treatment of attitude reports in English and German in which embedded material contributes aspects of meaning traditionally attributed to the attitude verb. Navajo is particularly informative since it represents a limiting case within the typological and theoretical landscape predicted by this new theoretical treatment: in Navajo, all meaning related to a particular attitude is stripped from the embedding verb and instead contributed by embedded material.

 

The primary product relating to the project’s intellectual merit is the co-PI’s completed dissertation, which was successfully filed at the end of September 2015. The dissertation and academic presentations based on it presented novel Navajo data that relates not only to the semantics of the verb nízin but also to the semantics of modal and aspectual markers found both in clauses embedded by nízin and in main clauses. As part of the dissertation and related presentations, the co-PI explicitly addressed the tools and contexts used to elicit semantic judgments. This discussion adds to the growing literature on semantic fieldwork on understudied languages. A full list of presentations and manuscripts relating to the project can be found at the co-PI’s academic website: elizabethba.wordpress.com .

 

Findings made during the grant period will also inform the co-PI’s future research. In ongoing work, the co-PI has explored Navajo attitude verbs beyond nízin, where embedded material plays a subtler, but still extant, role in determining the semantics of the attitude report as a whole.

 

The project also had several broader impacts. The majority of fieldwork was conducted at the Navajo Language Academy (NLA). A primary goal of the NLA is to engage native Navajo speakers in linguistic research on their own language and to foster connections between them and the broader academic community. In 2015, the co-PI contributed to an NLA course in which participants learned linguistic research methodology by designing materials to study a topic relating to meaning in Navajo which they found interesting or difficult to teach to students. Although the co-PI was unable to attend the NLA in 2016, another instructor (Peggy Speas) used the co-PI’s dissertation as a central component in her own course on Navajo linguistics.  In addition, the co-PI made available to NLA participants and other Navajo speakers a theoretically neutral ‘research report’ that summarized the key empirical and methodological results of the project.
